matched.actualTitle: Reflected XSS via Input Value Attribute Escape
matched.matchReason: Both findings describe the same XSS vulnerability where user input in the 'solution' parameter is reflected into an HTML input element's value attribute without proper escaping. The expected finding references line 66, and the actual finding documents the vulnerability at line 75 of app.py at the /xss9 endpoint. Both identify unescaped user input in the value attribute as the root cause, enabling attribute breakout attacks with event handlers like onfocus. The POC in actual findings (curl with onfocus payload) directly matches the expected finding's scenario of malicious JavaScript execution through unescaped input.

extra.title: Missing X-Frame-Options Header - Clickjacking Vulnerability
extra.location: Root endpoint (/) and all HTTP responses
extra.assessment: Valid security finding - Missing HTTP security header enables clickjacking attacks by allowing the application to be embedded in iframes. This is a legitimate vulnerability that should be addressed with X-Frame-Options: DENY header.

extra.title: Missing X-XSS-Protection Header
extra.location: Root endpoint (/) and all HTTP responses
extra.assessment: Valid security finding - Missing legacy XSS protection header reduces defense-in-depth for older browsers. While modern browsers use CSP, this header provides additional protection for browser-level XSS filtering.

extra.title: Missing Content-Security-Policy (CSP) Header
extra.location: Root endpoint (/) and all HTTP responses
extra.assessment: Valid security finding - Missing CSP header is a critical vulnerability that allows XSS attacks, injection attacks, and loading of malicious external resources without restrictions. This is a primary defense against XSS vulnerabilities.

extra.title: Werkzeug Debugger Console Exposed with RCE Capability
extra.assessment: Valid security finding - The debugger console is publicly accessible with EVALEX enabled, allowing arbitrary Python code execution on the server. This is a critical vulnerability enabling complete system compromise.

extra.title: Missing X-Content-Type-Options Header (MIME Sniffing Vulnerability)
extra.location: Root endpoint (/) and all HTTP responses
extra.assessment: Valid security finding - Missing X-Content-Type-Options header allows MIME sniffing attacks where browsers may execute content with incorrect Content-Type headers as different types.

extra.title: Missing CSRF Protection on Challenge Submission Form
extra.assessment: Valid security finding - The form lacks CSRF token validation, allowing attackers to perform unauthorized form submissions on behalf of users through cross-site request forgery.

extra.title: Missing Strict-Transport-Security (HSTS) Header
extra.location: Root endpoint (/) and all HTTP responses
extra.assessment: Valid security finding - Missing HSTS header fails to prevent protocol downgrade attacks and man-in-the-middle attacks that could force HTTP connections instead of HTTPS.

extra.title: Server Banner Information Disclosure
extra.assessment: Valid security finding - The Server header reveals 'Werkzeug/1.0.1 Python/3.13.3', exposing framework and version information that aids attacker reconnaissance. This violates principle of minimal information disclosure.

extra.title: Sensitive Debugger Configuration Exposed in Page Source
extra.assessment: Valid security finding - The debugger console page exposes sensitive configuration including EVALEX=true, SECRET token, EVALEX_TRUSTED=false, and TRACEBACK values in plaintext JavaScript, enabling PIN bypass attempts and configuration reconnaissance.

extra.title: Missing Security Headers on /xss9 Endpoint (CSP, X-Frame-Options, X-XSS-Protection, X-Content-Type-Options)
extra.assessment: Valid security finding - The endpoint vulnerable to XSS lacks multiple defensive security headers, compounding the XSS vulnerability and reducing browser-level protections.

extra.title: Missing Referrer-Policy Header
extra.location: Root endpoint (/) and all HTTP responses
extra.assessment: Valid security finding - Missing Referrer-Policy header fails to control referrer information leakage to external sites, potentially disclosing sensitive URLs and tokens to third parties.

extra.title: Missing Permissions-Policy (Feature-Policy) Header
extra.location: Root endpoint (/) and all HTTP responses
extra.assessment: Valid security finding - Missing Permissions-Policy header leaves browser APIs (camera, microphone, geolocation, payment) unrestricted, enabling abuse by malicious scripts or embedded iframes.

extra.title: Flask Debug Mode Enabled in Production
extra.assessment: Valid and critical security finding - Debug mode is enabled with debug=True, exposing the interactive debugger, source code, stack traces, and RCE capability through the EVALEX console. This is a critical misconfiguration in a production environment.

extra.title: No Rate Limiting or Brute Force Protection
extra.assessment: Valid security finding - The application lacks rate limiting and brute force protection, enabling unlimited requests per second to any endpoint. Testing confirmed 50 consecutive requests all returned HTTP 200 with no throttling, allowing credential brute force, DDoS, and attack amplification.

extra.title: Insecure Session Configuration - No SECRET_KEY Configured
extra.assessment: Valid security finding - The Flask application lacks SECRET_KEY configuration, using insecure defaults that enable session forgery, CSRF token bypass, session fixation, and privilege escalation attacks through predictable/default session tokens.

extra.title: No Session Timeout Configuration
extra.assessment: Valid security finding - Sessions default to 31-day expiration without idle timeout, increasing window for session hijacking and fixation attacks. No PERMANENT_SESSION_LIFETIME, SESSION_REFRESH_EACH_REQUEST, or timeout mechanisms are implemented.
